title: I'm sorry but I can NEVER give credit to Yasuo mains...
body:
I know people are going to hate me for this but I've played him and I've seen him played and his kit is just so bloody easy.

I'm sorry if I offend Yasuo mains but it really is... he doesn't need to worry about mana, he gets a free shield just for WALKING. He has no variation in his build so you build the same thing every game and he has near infinite mobility when minions are in lane (which is constantly). He has an ability that blocks other champions ultimates.

HOW is this champion hard exactly? Can somebody please explain this to me because I just don't see it. I can't understand why people say he's "high skill" because he has NO MANA. He can spam his abilities, with minimal cooldown all day and not suffer any consequences and his Q has a deceptively long range as well.

think ive figure out the core of why Yasuo is so Annoying, its his passive shield and ability to just sit on your face and just 2X Q you then knock you up leaving little room to react. Riot has stated that it can be unhealthy for melee champions to ONLY be about getting on a target and sticking to them no matter what to deal damage, thats why recent melee champions have been given ways to encourage them to his at a distance. Yasuo can and will stick as close as he can to a target to damage them, and his 3rd Q, in addition to E affords him the stickiness he needs. If his 3rd Q encouraged him to move back to get the most out of it it would offer opponents a chance to breathe against the slew of not only damage but CC and defense that he can put up.

Ive come up with some appropriate changes

Yasuo: 3rd Q only knocks up a little or not at all at close range and more at max range.
R deals damage based on the amount of time the targets have spent in the air. Basically the higher they get knocked up the more damage it deals. Yay more skill!

They could also put the 3rd Q on its own CD, if it misses an enemy champ it goes on a longer CD.

Another reason Yasuo feels unfair IS the amount of defense he has for the damage he can put out. His passive shield is especially annoying for a few reasons, unlike other champions he doesn't have to cast abilities (that normally cost something) or hit enemy champion to charge it, he just has to move which can be considered uninteractive since the opponent doesn't get to do anything about it. Also it doesn't feel skillful for the Yasuo player to get the shield, all he has to do is move around, now sure you can move around alot to charge it at the last second IF there are enough units near by...but does is moving around using E or right clicking REALLY all that skillful? Not only that but if a Good Yasuo player IS moving around using E or moving they can ALSO use that to dodge skillshots/avoid enemies, and then they have a shield that they can use to tank the next ability or AA, and its passive so Yasuo ALWAYS gets to charge it, and theres NO CD. And once its up it stays. AND tower shots don't even make it go away, not saying the shield should block a tower shot, but its weird that Tower shots dont just destroy the shield. Other passive shields are just consumed based on the damage dealt to them and dont stick around once destroyed.

his passive, W, ult to refresh passive (and keep him out of tower range, this is TOO much safety for all the damage he can dish out, he gets to play like some sort of situational tank)

his passive should should just be deleted instead Rework W so it has a longer CD but it gets reduced by moving and change it so it acts more like a directional spell shield (its up for 0.75 sec and then its gone).

less annoying + a bit more skill = less skilled people playing Yasuo + less hate

I think another excellent change for Yasuo would be to remove the ability to piggy back off of allied CC with his R; that would allow major buffs to his kit and his R especially.

Another way increase the incentive for Yasuo players to use the own knock up is to code the 3rd Q to have the one of the highest knock ups at max range. Now it doesn't NEED to actually have a longer/higher knock up, but his R can just _treat_ it like that's the case (so Yasuo doesn't get unnecessary additional utility). This encourages Yasuo players to use their own knock up skillfull at max range to max their dmg output. This way you won't have Yasuo players using their ult off Vel'koz E's, they _could_ but the dmg would be MUCH lower.

The issue with Yasuo is more about ppl refusing to counterplay him because it would mean to adapt your playstyle to the enemy pick... **Which is the very definition of counterplay to begin with!**

I've played as and against Yasuo and if you know what he does and keep an eye on him as you would do for Fiora, Trynda, Yi or any other carry then it all comes down to mechanical skill because every1 has the tools to face Yasuo and some can litterally walk over him.

The problem is that Yasuo always has the initiative. This is actually a problem that a lot of riot's champions over the past 3 years or so have, where their kit designs mechanically behave as counterplay to champions, while other champions are forced to invest in counterplay items to have a chance against the champion.

Imagine if you're in a fist fight, and you're only allowed to move sideways and backwards. That's what it feels like to play against a Yasuo, yes you can win, but even when ahead you're forced to be on the back foot. You can only play around him, while it's almost impossible for a Yasuo to lose the initiative and leading pressure in the fight. It's simply terrible design.

He is a melee champion heavily incentivized to build relatively squishy early, his play pattern is fairly mechanically intensive and requires you learning how to manage your Q stacks, minion waves and minion positioning for E, and how to effectively use windwall, your only real defensive ability.

He is one of the harder champions to actually play in the game as a result. The claim of "lol free shield for just walking" is severely underplaying even the shield, which reinforces E uses to engage, disengage, dodge skillshots etc.

Yasuo arguably does have a very high skill cap. However, you only have to be a little aware of the basic games mechanics to use him effectively. It's like Zed, easy to get the grasp of, but with a lot of mechanical depth.

Unfortunately this does result in them coming off as easy to play, despite the higher end of their gameplay. A really good yasuo is infinitely scarier than a moderately decent one.

and we're still insulting Yasuo players.

Why?

Because he's feels awful to play against and suffers from Shaco Syndrome.

I don't enjoy spending laning phase dodging his 3rd Q every 9 seconds and staying 500 units away from him and my minions at all times, because he'll dash on me, auto or Q me once and dash away, winning trade based solely on his shield, with limited options to retaliate for me. 

I hate how I can spend laning phase thrashing him, smashing him into the ground, but as long as he has one person on his team with an AoE knockup, he will still be useful and the moment he hits two items he will be relevant again.

I don't like that if I play an ADC, I can be nullified by a single basic ability with an 18 second cooldown late game and a 4 second duration, which eventually covers half a lane. 

I don't enjoy feeling like I need to be 12/0 before _I _ am the one who has the initiative, before _I_ am the one who needs to be respected. 

I don't ban Yasuo because he's good. I ban him because _He makes me hate the game when I'm playing against him._ I'm sure someone will go "ur silver get gud" but I honestly don't give a shit. I play games to have fun, and playing against Yasuo is the antithesis of me having fun.

Yasuo is hard mostly because he doesn't have a great laning phase. He also has a lot of outplay potential, but is also vulnerable to ganks without his E. His playstyle is either to get fed or feed, since he's very squishy. In teamfights you have to weave around the millions of CC abilities enemies have because you die instantly without something like QSS. Yes, he may get 100% crit easily, but with new crit changes he also gets them later than usual. He is hard in his own ways, but easy in other aspects.

So is Yasuo hard?
Yes, he is difficult in a general stance. But is he the hardest in League? No, since champions like Zed or Azir are more mechanically difficult to just learn.
